items.title: API changes regarding customizing characters
Update the tutorial about streaming tables
items.body: Streaming tables are not mentioned in the tutorial.

items.title: Support row headers
items.body:
This would be useful where there are too many headers to fit in the terminal, but only a few rows. Something along the lines:

```
print(table.transposed())
```

would be super helpful.

items.title: Properly Document the behaviour of manual setting of column_widths
items.body:
This has been a common query across many users. See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49454626/how-to-set-cell-width-size-for-beautifultable/60418950#60418950

Basically on every call to `__str__`, the width are recalculated overwriting the current widths. User is supposed to call the `get_string` method with `recalculate_width` as `False` but this should be documented more properly and made more prominent. An alternative solution would be to have a new attribute say `disable_auto_width` and use that to control the behaviour of `__str__`.

items.title: allow zero for padding widths
items.body:
Sometimes data does not need to be padded at all (e.g. single alphanumerics, or checkmarks).

Currently `set_padding_widths` accepts 0 but this seems to have no effect, and `default_padding` does not accept 0 at all.

Would it be possible to allow for zero padding?

items.title: Tests are failing
items.body:
On Fedora some tests are failing (https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1812435#c1)

Could you please take a look? Thanks in advance.

items.title: Drop python 2 support
items.body: WIth Python 2 going EOL, we should drop support for it. Will allow to simplify some modules.

items.title: Add a filter method to get rows satisfying a certain condition
items.body: A filter method will be handy for certain use cases which returns a table with only those rows which satisfies a certain condition.

items.title: Allow sort based on an arbitrary callable
items.body: Currently we can sort the table based on a column. But we should allow the use of any callable as a key function like the sort method of list.

items.title: Avoid double release to pypi from travis
Allow import and export from formats like csv
Allow cell level styling
items.body: We should allow the user to specify alignment, padding, etc per cell instead of restricting to column only. This would allow the table to be much more configurable and allow use cases such as having one row differently aligned than the other.

items.title: Drop Python 3.3 support
items.body: Python 3.3 has been EOL for a long time.

items.title: Allow setting alignment for header row separately
items.body: I use the `default_alignment` to set `ALIGN_LEFT`, but I want to keep the header row with `ALIGN_CENTER`. I can't see a way to that.

items.title: Underscore in data between 2 digits is stripped
items.body:
See image for debugging data.

table.append_row(['1234', '10-100', '1d 4h']) #all good
table.append_row(['1234_5678', '10-_00', '1d_4h']) #Underscore in first string is stripped. The other 2 instances are not stripped (for whatever reason). Seems to only be underscore between digits in a string.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16825179/57820417-ba6d5480-775a-11e9-924d-81146e3c6dbc.png)

items.title: Allow setting alignment, etc for all columns more easily
items.body:
The following syntax could be used to align all columns with a simple statement.

```
table.column_alignments = beautifultable.ALIGN_LEFT
```

items.title: Is it possible to print table row by row from generator without buffering it earlier?
items.body:
Hi,
is it possible to print table row by row (f.e. from generator) without buffering it earlier. I have to print quite large amount of data and collecting it takes some time. With this option process of printing large data would look nicer :)

items.title: Version 0.7 BT: UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position 0-138: ordinal not in range(128)
items.body:
I encountered this error using beautifultable v0.70 in python2.7. 

`UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position 0-138: ordinal not in range(128) `

It occurred during 

`print(table)`

when I used:
```
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
from __future__ import unicode_literals
```

or 
```
from __future__ import unicode_literals
import sys
reload(sys)
sys.setdefaultencoding('utf-8')
```
It printed nothing but noisy results:
`â•­â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
`

items.title: Misaligned when using colored strings via module Blessings
items.body:
The printed table is misaligned when using colored data via module Blessings.
Here is an example.

```
from beautifultable import BeautifulTable
import blessings

term = blessings.Terminal()

table = BeautifulTable(max_width=120)

table.column_headers = [term.green('Header A'), term.cyan('Header B')]
table.append_row([term.yellow('data'), term.cyan('data')])

print(table)
```
Tested on:
- Python 3.6.7 (default, Oct 22 2018, 11:32:17)

Screenshot of output:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1115421/52619111-e0b6f600-2ec6-11e9-9269-8529709a1b44.png)

items.title: Add new styles using unicode characters
items.body: After #53 is merged, we can now use different characters for different points of intersections which makes box tables a possibility using unicode characters such as in http://jrgraphix.net/r/Unicode/2500-257F

items.title: breaking on python 2;
items.body:
This seems to be breaking on python 2.

```
>>> import beautifultable
>>> t = beautifultable.BeautifulTable()
>>> t.column_headers = ["a", "b", "c"]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/russ/.pyenv/versions/2.7.10/lib/python2.7/site-packages/beautifultable/beautifultable.py", line 231, in __setattr__
    super(BeautifulTable, self).__setattr__(name, value)
  File "/Users/russ/.pyenv/versions/2.7.10/lib/python2.7/site-packages/beautifultable/beautifultable.py", line 366, in column_headers
    raise TypeError("Headers should be of type 'str', not {}".format(type(i)))
TypeError: Headers should be of type 'str', not <type 'str'>
```

items.title: Support for subtables
items.body: In e4d41c2 , ability to handle newline character was added. Hence with proper max_widths, another table could be in a cell of parent table. Logic could be added to adjust the max_width to ensure internal tables are not wrapped or stripped.

items.title: Make wcwidth an optional dependency
Allow more finer customization
items.body: - `intersection_char` could be expanded into multiple types based on shape. will allow for more customization. #53

items.title: Expand Tutorial/Quickstart to include recent additions
items.body:
[Tutorial](https://beautifultable.readthedocs.io/en/latest/quickstart.html) hasn't been updated in a while. The following could be included in it:

- Coloured texts
- changing paragraphs(using `\n`)
- Styles
- Subtables

items.title: Improper table if column_width is calculated to be too low
items.body:
# Test case

```
table = BeautifulTable(max_width=30)
table.column_headers = ["name", "rank", "gender"]
table.append_row(["Sophia", 2, "girl"*20])
table.append_row(["Michael", 3, "boy"])
print(table)
```

# Output

```+--+------+------------------+
|  | rank |      gender      |
| n |      |                  |
| a |      |                  |
| m |      |                  |
| e |      |                  |
+--+------+------------------+
|  |  2   | girlgirlgirlgirl |
| S |      | girlgirlgirlgirl |
| o |      | girlgirlgirlgirl |
| p |      | girlgirlgirlgirl |
| h |      | girlgirlgirlgirl |
| i |      |                  |
| a |      |                  |
+--+------+------------------+
|  |  3   |       boy        |
| M |      |                  |
| i |      |                  |
| c |      |                  |
| h |      |                  |
| a |      |                  |
| e |      |                  |
| l |      |                  |
+--+------+------------------+```

items.title: Malformed table when using WEP_STRIP or WEP_ELLIPSIS with multibyte characters
Use tox to run tests on Travis
items.body: See https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

items.title: Handle newlines
items.body:
## Test Case
```python
from beautifultable import BeautifulTable

x = BeautifulTable()
x.append_row(["0", "a\nb"])
print(x)
```

## Expected output
```
+---+---+
| 0 | a |
|   | b |
+---+---+
```
## Actual Output
```
+---+-----+
| 0 | a
b |
+---+-----+
```

items.title: beautifultable is not beautiful for multibyte string
items.body:
Hi, 
I'm trying to print multibyte string in beautifultable. But the result is not beautiful, unsuitable number of space.

like this:
```python
from beautifultable import BeautifulTable
table = BeautifulTable()
table.column_headers = ['Language', 'Hello']
table.append_row(['Japanese', 'こんにちは'])
table.append_row(['English', 'Hello'])
table.append_row(['Chinese', '你好'])
table.append_row(['Emoji', '😉'])
print(table)
```
```
+----------+-------+
| Language | Hello |
+----------+-------+
| Japanese | こんにちは |
+----------+-------+
| English  | Hello |
+----------+-------+
| Chinese  |  你好   |
+----------+-------+
|  Emoji   |   😉   |
+----------+-------+
```

Is there any way to solve this problem?
Thanks.

```
$ pip freeze | grep beautifultable
beautifultable==0.5.3
```

items.title: ResourseWarning and UserWarning cant be ingnored.
items.body:
Hi,
First of all this is a great tool that im planning on using in my own project as a replacement for pandas dataframe. I love that you can index the elements inside a table unlike many other table packages. 

However, everytime I print the a table to the console inside my own project I get the following warnings:
`UserWarning: nperseg = 256 is greater than input length  = 10, using nperseg = 10
  .format(nperseg, input_length))`
`sys:1: ResourceWarning: unclosed file <_io.TextIOWrapper name=1 mode='w' encoding='utf8'>`

The first warning is a result of my own builtin function and I have successfully filtered out that warning but it always pops back up whenever I use your tool to print a table to the console. Warning number two only appears if I use your tool. I tried suppressing the warning by doing:
`simplefilter('ignore', UserWarning)`
`simplefilter('ignore', ResourceWarning)`

but it just wont go away. DO you have any suggestions on how to deal with this issue?

items.title: Test with python 3.7 on travis
items.body: Currently travis seems to have some issue with 3.7(see https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/9815).

items.title: collections ABCs deprecation warning
items.body:
As mentioned in #36, Using collections.Iterable has been deprecated in 3.7 and will stop working in 3.8
Fix should be similar to https://github.com/pyparsing/pyparsing/pull/16

items.title: Handling ANSI escape sequences
items.body: We should handle ANSI escape sequences so that the table isn't messed up when using colored output in the terminal.

items.title: Maintain a changelog for all new and old releases
problem in adding coloration to the table elements
items.body: I tried to use the library colored to add colors to table elements, but when printing, the formatting was rendered to plain text.  I just now saw that Style_NONE was applied. Is the problem due to this command? how can i turn it to manual?

items.title: Non-string floats are rounded to integers after the 0.5.1 release
items.body: If detect_numerics is `True`, which is by default, then any non-string floats are rounded to integers.

items.title: Is there a way not to print Column Headers
items.body:
_Hi there - thank you for a great product._
I have table of data that is formatted just perfectly HOWEVER I do **NOT** want the column headers to be printed.
**Is there a way I can stop the column headers from being printed.**

Thank you very much

_PJ_

items.title: added float 2.0 return int 2
items.body:
#1 issue
if we add row value 2.0.
Then it prints 2.
https://github.com/pri22296/beautifultable/blob/master/beautifultable/utils.py#L13
2.0.is_integer()#True
You should return Item.

items.title: Incorrect calculation of column width
column_widths doesn't appear to be working
items.body:
The content and header names for my table are being wrapped. To avoid this, I'm setting table.column_widths, as per the docs, such as

`table.column_widths = [30, 30, 30]`

But it doesn't seem to have any effect.

Is there are more correct way to establish column widths?

items.title: Length of a escape sequence inside a string is taken into account
items.body:
The length of a escape sequence is taken into account when calculating the col-width.
This is a problem when you want to display a colored string.

For example:

open = \033[1;32open\033[0m

-------------------+
open |
-------------------+

items.title: String improperly being converted to float
items.body:
I have an element I'm trying to add to my table and it's the string "2e77754" which is an ID number for something. This gets improperly recognized as a float with value 2x10^77754 and thus returns "inf" in my table instead of the string "2e77754".

I think the issue is in `/beautifultable/utils/convert_to_numeric.py`

items.title: row_count would be very helpful to have
items.body: First, thanks for the awesome tool!  I'm just getting started with Python, so I'm not quite ready to figure out how to add this myself, but would it be possible to add a row_count method, similar to column_count?

items.title: typo in separator fields
items.body: All separator fields are spelled as seperator. It's not a major issue but needs fixing. It is desirable that the fix is backcompatible.

items.title: Corrupted table view with long table
items.body:
```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3

from beautifultable import BeautifulTable

table = BeautifulTable()
table.column_headers = list(["Name" for x in range(100)])
table.append_row(list(["Name" for x in range(100)]))

print(table)
```
Become to:
```
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
| Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na |
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
| Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na | Na |
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
```

items.title: Float print formatting broken?
items.body:
This seemed off to me:

python -c "import beautifultable; t = beautifultable.BeautifulTable(); t.append_row(['3.14']); print('%s' % t)"

I get:
+--------------------+
| 3.1400000000000001 |
+--------------------+

when I expect:

+------+
| 3.14 |
+------+

Since I actually specified the row as a string I'm surprised to see was treated as a float (float gives same behavior).

items.title: Order of sorting
items.body: Hello! Don't find the sorting order of table. For example ascending or descending ordering. Is this method in your lib?

items.title: How can I align the table?
items.body:
Hello! The problem on screen. How can I align it?

items.title: enums in < python 3.4
items.body:
`import enum` [beautifultable/enums.py](https://github.com/pri22296/beautifultable/blob/master/beautifultable/enums.py#L1)
enum exists only in Python 3.4 and onwards. If you want to support versions below (2.7 too) you have to add [enum34](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/enum34) to your requires for the specific versions.

items.title: Print to string
items.body: Print prints to terminal. I would need something that can put the output in a string instead.

items.title: Print statement resets column widths
items.body:
Whenever I use `column_widths` to change this parameter for a column and then run `print(table)`, it resets the column's width back to the previous value.
So I have to use `print(table.get_string(recalculate_width=False))` instead of the simple print statement.

items.title: Different behaviour on Python 2 and 3
Exception on WEP_ELLIPSIS AND content length less than 3
signmode does not work
Should print nothing if table is empty
items.body:
Currently prints
+
||
+
+

items.title: Inconsistent behavior on printing
items.body:
```
>>> from beautifultable import BeautifulTable
>>> table = BeautifulTable()
>>> table.append_row([1])
>>> table.pop_row()
>>> print(table)
+--+
|  |
+--+
+--+
>>> table.append_row([1])
>>> table.pop_column()
>>> print(table)
+
||
+
+
```

items.title: beautifultable prints header even when not set explicitly
items.body:
When header are not explicitly set, the expected behavior should be not to print the header row.
currently, a blank row is printed.

items.title: automatically show serial number of rows based on a bool value
Display supported python versions on README
Setup test coverage on travis
Basic usage instruction should be on README
Setup automatic release on pypi on tagged commits using travis
Documentation does not seems to update on Readthedocs
items.body: Docs seems to update locally, but not on [readthedocs](http://beautifultable.readthedocs.io/en/latest/). Currently we need to wipe the docs and rebuild but that is not Practical.
